ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Kristin took the course very seriously and offered amazing feedback on written assignments. Adan was also a very capable and knowledgeable TA and added immensely to the class experience.
This is a great course, and opens up a discourse that has hitherto been missing from classes at FES--oneabout where food/ag and social justice intersect.
I am glad I bought the book, but wasn't really necessary for class since it was all scanned into v2 anyway.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The class discussions were on the whole very good, some of the best I've had at Yale. The field trip tothe Yale Farm was good, and I enjoyed the lightening presentations at the end of the course.
The readings were very interesting and, even though it may have been overwhelming or annoying at the time, being forced to write weekly reading responses was a truly helpful exercise.
I really enjoyed and learned a lot from the readings. I also enjoyed having guest speakers and hearing their perspectives.
Great group for discussion. Very interesting concepts. Loved the anti-oppression exercise and the broad coverage of readings.

The breadth of course readings was nice, since it gave us a good perspective on many current issues in the field. Also, the organization of the course seemed to bring us back to recurring themes from different angles which was nice, since concepts began to build on each other in interesting ways, which made class discussions get much richer as the course went on.

BEST CLASS AT FES BY FAR. I loved it. Not only was the material so helpful in my critical thinking, the class was dynamic, the readings relevant and Kristin did a great job at facilitating while not dominating the discussion. Discussions were great and sometimes pushed some comfort levels, but the class also simultaneously was a very safe space and very encouraging. A testament to the class is that we sort of became a little family toward the end and I always looked forward to it.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The reading list could be tightened up a bit -- it seemed like there was a fair amount of repetition in topics and content.

The course was mostly discussion-based, which was good, but sometimes the discussions needed more structure and seemed to ramble in odd directions. I think having a concluding comment from the instructor at the end of each discussion would have helped tie things together and leave students with a better sense of what just took place.

Would be great if there were a little more structure to the discussion. Maybe at the end of the day the professor could leave the class with some thinking points to connect weekly sessions after our broader conversations.Expected it to be a bit more practical/geared to actors in the field about how to dismantle oppression in the food system. It did give us the mindset, but not a bunch of practical contacts with actors or experiences. Was very theoretical, but interesting nonetheless.
I think some (very few) of the readings could be changed in order to be more current or more helpful. There were two or three that seemed to contribute less to the course than they should have.
More feedback/grading during semester to reading responses.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very strong connection -- they informed the other well.
n/a
Discussions were great, and really helped me to better understand all the material we were going through.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Not directly related, but is an incredible interest of mine that I was glad to have had the opportunity to engage in.

My thesis is about small-scale agriculture, so this course was very relevant. It provided me with a new lens for thinking about a lot of my research, and encouraged me to think more critically about my own work.

Social justice is a new area I wish to explore, and one that is inevitably linked more and more with environmental crises. I am interested in learning about social justice not just in the food system but also in other environmental issues like climate change.
I am interested in food and agricultural issues, so this class was a direct part of that interest with its focus on the food system.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in food systems, food, agricultural development, and social justice.
I am interested in social justice issues.
I'm fascinated my the subject material, and as someone who studies food systems, agriculture, and the cultural importance of food, I felt it would be an important set of material to be exposed to.
See above.
The topic is directly relevant to my academic and career goals.
It relates to my research and area of interest

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely -- came out with a lot more knowledge than I had going in.
Yes, it was a really great course that enhanced my first semester.
Yes.
Yes. I thought it would have more of an international focus, but I still find a way to apply the concepts.
Yes, it was fantastic
Expanded critical thinking in terms of how environmental justice plays out in the US.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be tolerant, and be willing to think critically about race and class.
Be prepared to contribute in class.

This is a really great course. Even if you don't directly study food/agriculture, I think you would find it valuable and interesting. The readings are thought-provoking, and class discussions were always stimulating.

Take it if you are interested in the theoretical underpinnings of social justice in the food movement, and if you are interested in the U.S. focus. There is not a lot about international communities or the developing world here.
Read read read, and make sure you understand as much as you can. Also, keep up with work on your final paper because the deadline comes at you fast once you get past thanksgiving.
I HOPE THIS IS TAUGHT AGAIN. BEST CLASS SO FAR AT FES.
